content: The National Science Foundation Authorization Act of 2002 is amended to authorize $9,839,262,000 for fiscal year 2007, with $50,000,000 allocated for Partnerships for Access to Laboratory Sciences. The National Science Foundation Authorization Act of 2002 authorizes funding for Partnerships for Access to Laboratory Sciences (PALS) to enhance access to laboratory science. The National Science Foundation Authorization Act of 2002 authorizes grants for high-need local educational agencies to improve laboratory access and quality of STEM instruction at the secondary school level. Grants are awarded competitively based on merit. The National Science Foundation Authorization Act of 2002 authorizes grants for high-need local educational agencies to improve STEM instruction at the secondary school level through competitive, merit-based awards. Eligible agencies must form partnerships with higher education institutions, community colleges, businesses, or nonprofit organizations. The National Science Foundation Authorization Act of 2002 authorizes grants for high-need local educational agencies to improve STEM instruction at the secondary school level through partnerships with higher education institutions, community colleges, businesses, and nonprofit organizations. The Federal share of the cost of activities shall not exceed 33 percent. The Federal share of the cost for activities under the grant shall not exceed 33 percent. A high-need local educational agency approved for a grant can receive funding for 3 fiscal years. To be eligible for the grant, the agency must submit a plan to the Director. To be eligible for a grant under this section, a high-need local educational agency must submit a plan to the Director, developed in consultation with various experts, describing how the proposed laboratory improvements align with State academic standards. The plan for a grant under this section must describe how laboratory improvements align with State academic standards and enhance mathematics, science, engineering, and technology instruction to produce clear learning outcomes. The grant plan must describe how laboratory experiences in mathematics, science, engineering, and technology are designed to produce clear learning outcomes, complement classroom instruction, integrate science content, and incorporate student reflection and discussion. Professional development must also be described. The grant plan must include professional development for teachers and school personnel working in the laboratory facilities, ensure safety requirements are met, and outline maintenance of the laboratory and instrumentation. Additionally, assessment methods will be used to expand research literature on the effect of laboratory science on student understanding and achievement. Grants awarded under this section will meet State or local requirements and describe post-grant maintenance of the laboratory and instrumentation. The grant funds will be used to supplement existing programs and improve secondary science education by enhancing laboratories and providing instrumentation. The grant funds will be used to improve secondary science education by enhancing laboratories and providing instrumentation as part of a comprehensive program to enhance the quality of mathematics, science, engineering, and technology instruction at the secondary school level. The curr_chunk focuses on improving laboratory facilities and instrumentation in line with State mathematics and science academic standards. This includes developing a plan for laboratory improvement, purchasing equipment and materials, and maintaining and renovating laboratory facilities. The curr_chunk focuses on funding for scientific educational materials, maintenance, renovation, teacher training, curriculum development, and laboratory safety training for school personnel. The curr_chunk focuses on integrating laboratory experience with classroom instruction, training school personnel in laboratory safety, and implementing hands-on laboratory experiences to encourage interest in mathematics, science, and engineering. The curr_chunk focuses on supporting individuals interested in mathematics, science, engineering, and technology to pursue postsecondary studies in these fields. It includes the development of evaluation tools for funded activities and any other activities deemed necessary by the Director. The curr_chunk discusses the limitation on the use of funds for grants awarded under this section, specifying that they cannot be used for the construction of new facilities. Additionally, it outlines the selection process for high-need local educational agencies seeking a grant, requiring them to submit an application with specified information to the Director. Applicants seeking a grant must submit an application to the Director with specific information, including a partnership description, implementation roles, a plan, and details of activities to be funded. The grant application must include details of activities to be funded, aligned with academic standards, and promoting student achievement in mathematics and science. The grant application must include activities aligned with academic standards to promote student achievement in mathematics and science, based on research and best practices, expected to enhance student performance and strengthen instruction quality. The grant application should include activities to improve student performance in mathematics and science, as well as encourage interest in individuals from underrepresented groups in STEM fields. The grant application should include activities to improve student performance in mathematics, science, engineering, and technology, prepare individuals for postsecondary studies in these fields, assess changes in student achievement, assess partnership success, and make programmatic assessments available to the research community. The grant application should include activities to improve student performance in STEM fields, assess changes in student achievement, and describe how the partnership will assess its success and make programmatic assessments available to the research community. The partnership's evaluation criteria include alignment with state academic standards, potential for widespread implementation, and encouragement of interest in STEM fields among underrepresented individuals. The program established under this section will be evaluated using common benchmarks to identify best practices and materials developed by partnerships. The Director will disseminate evaluation results to specific committees in the House of Representatives and Senate, and make effective materials widely available to the public.
